texts.shortText: Rare but large, unusual and highly distinctive species that lives unattached to substratum. Column red or red-striped and can be squat or become narrow and elongated. Oral disc and foot inflated and marked with distinctive red and white radiating stripes, after which the common name is derived. Tentacles about 50, fat and with red and white longitudinal bands.
Up to about 10 cm in length when fully extended.

Global: Endemic.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to about Durban.

A spectacular species and one of few anemones that are not permanently attached to the substratum, but crawl or float around in search of prey. Originally described from Durban, but more recent records all from the Cape, where it appears to be most often encountered (a reminder of the danger of naming species after their original place of discovery!). Usually seen with the foot greatly expanded onto a ‘umbrella’ that probably aids in dispersal by waves and currents. When a sea fan is encountered the stomach is everted thought the mouth and the sea fan externally digested, leaving only a dead skeleton. The few specimens reported have been found on shallow reefs of 1–15 m depth.
Appears to feed only on gorgonians which are engulfed in situ and the soft tissues digested from the skeleton which is left bare as the anemone moves on.
No details known but assumed to reproduce sexually. Fission has not been observed to our knowledge.
Unmistakable in appearance and habits and unlikely to be confused with any other regional species.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Riemann-Zürneck, K & Griffiths, CL (1999). Korsaranthus natalensis (Carlgren, 1938) nov. comb. (Cnidaria: Actiniaria) a mobile sea anemone attacking octocorals. African Zoology, 34(4), 190–196.
